title: Attack of the Killer Tomatoes
descriptions:
In 1978’s Attack of the Killer Tomatoes, a series of bizarre and deadly incidents erupts across the United States: people are being attacked by tomatoes. What begins as a seemingly absurd tabloid headline quickly becomes a national emergency as ordinary produce inexplicably gains sentience and murderous intent. The government scrambles to contain the panic while news outlets seize on the sensational story, amplifying the chaos. Authorities at first deny the severity, but after a helicopter mysteriously crashes during a press conference and red-stained “crime scenes” multiply, the crisis can no longer be dismissed.

The President’s staff assembles a mismatched, covert task force led by the unflappably square Mason Dixon. His team includes an undercover master of disguise whose costumes barely fool anyone, a paratrooper who constantly finds himself stranded in ridiculous drop zones, a swimmer assigned to track aquatic tomatoes, and a radio operator whose competence is as questionable as the mission itself. Their orders: figure out what the tomatoes are, how they’re killing people, and how to stop them—preferably without causing further embarrassment to the administration.

As the attacks escalate—from kitchens to suburban yards to public spaces—the tomatoes grow bolder and larger, rolling and bouncing in menacing swarms. The film gleefully lampoons government bureaucracy and media sensationalism as officials hold inept briefings and spin the catastrophe in comically optimistic terms. A persistent reporter, Lois Fairchild, suspects there’s a cover-up and begins digging into Dixon’s operation, hoping to expose the truth and make her journalistic name.

Dixon’s team follows a trail of tomato-related mayhem to learn that the fruits aren’t just attacking at random; they respond to certain sounds and seem to organize. Meanwhile, a shadowy figure appears to be manipulating events from behind the scenes, suggesting the outbreak may not be purely natural. In a series of bungled operations, the task force tries everything from standard weapons to strategic traps, but bullets and explosions only pulp the tomatoes into more mess without stopping the larger threat. The crisis reaches a tipping point when giant tomatoes—some the size of small cars—roll through town, scattering citizens and overwhelming local defenses.

Comedic misadventures pile up: the master of disguise infiltrates tomato gatherings with ludicrous outfits, the swimmer stalks tomatoes through sprinklers and sewers, and the paratrooper wanders suburbia with his chute perpetually tangled. Through trial and error, Dixon and Lois realize the tomatoes are vulnerable not to force, but to a particular cultural artifact: a cheesy, relentlessly upbeat song. When played at high volume, the tune disrupts the tomatoes, causing them to shrivel and burst. This discovery leads to a final plan to lure the ravaging red tide into a stadium and blast the music loud enough to end the assault.

As people cram into shelters and military units prepare for a last stand, Dixon and his team coordinate the sonic offensive, racing against time while the tomatoes batter the city. The music strategy works: the killer tomatoes convulse, deflate, and dissolve under the power of kitschy pop, an ultimate joke about the weaponization of bad taste. In the aftermath, the mastermind behind the tomato uprising is unmasked, and the film takes one more jab at political opportunists and conspiracy-laden thinking.

Order returns, the task force improbably gets credit, and Dixon shares a wry moment with Lois, who lands her big story. But in a final gag, the film hints that the vegetable aisle may not be safe for long: a carrot ominously twitches, suggesting that produce-related terror could be only beginning. Equal parts parody, slapstick, and low-budget ingenuity, Attack of the Killer Tomatoes treats its absurd premise with deadpan seriousness, skewering disaster movies, government incompetence, and media hype while celebrating the joy of a deliberately silly B-movie.
